Posted By: Gwafa_Hazid (5/3/2010 7:47:43 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I love that card.  
Unless your opponent has ways to get rid of the enchanted creature, you'll have a delayed [Unsummon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Unsummon) every turn - great tech against aggro! Most often mana advantage for you.  
  
And, on top of that, you can also use it on your creatures in case you want to bounce them for re-using their cip/etb trigger again. Especially if you cast it on those with Echo.  
  
Talking about these, returning enchantments might be profitable as well if those Auras also trigger, e.g. [Sisay's Ingenuity](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sisay's Ingenuity), [Fists of Ironwood](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Fists of Ironwood) and others.   
  
(Watch what you're going to return to your opponent, of course. You won't want him/her to cast a [Flametongue Kavu](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Flametongue Kavu) a second time)
posts.html:

And, on top of that, you can also use it on your creatures in case you want to bounce them for re-using their cip/etb trigger again. Especially if you cast it on those with Echo.

Talking about these, returning enchantments might be profitable as well if those Auras also trigger, e.g. Sisay's Ingenuity, Fists of Ironwood and others.

(Watch what you're going to return to your opponent, of course. You won't want him/her to cast a Flametongue Kavu a second time)

posts.post_content:
First off, gorgeous design; can we see a reprint with a cycle attached?  
  
Red- 2 or 3 damage to that creature  
Black- negative counters maybe  
White- Gain life (political if enough life is gained)  
Green- add mana / destroy with flying  
Blue- This   
  
  
Second, I like [Leyline of Anticipation](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Leyline of Anticipation), but let's get silly here. That plus [paradox haze](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=paradox haze) will mess with your opponent.

Posted By: KvotheBloodless (11/4/2013 7:12:07 AM)
Rating:

@Repete - just to be perfectly accurate, Mark of Eviction + scry isn't card advantage. However, it's very good draw filtering, and as we've seen from cards like Preordain, Ponder and Sensei's Divining Top, draw filtering can often be as good, if not better than raw card advantage.

Of course, it's very easy to generate card advantage with this. For as little as 2 mana you can get creatures with draw-a-card ETBs like Wall of Omens or Elvish Visionary. And plenty of other abilities which are similar to draw a card, like Coiling Oracle or Augur of Bolas.

One overlooked thing is that you're getting to cast a spell each turn, for 1 mana. So if you're playing a card that cares about spellcasting - such as the new Consuming Aberration (5 mana UB mill creature from Gatecrash) - you can get a lot of value out of it.
